final_answer:
The humor or satire in this image stems from the juxtaposition of two contrasting scenes alongside the text "YES, BUT." 

On the left, the referee is happily holding up a trophy, which implies a celebratory moment of winning or success. However, on the right, the silhouette of a boxer is paint-splattered, creating an ironic contrast. This suggests that while there is acknowledgment of success ("YES"), there is also an underlying issue or mess ("BUT"), symbolized by the boxer being covered in paint.

This contrast humorously highlights the idea that success might not be as clean or straightforward as it seems, and there might be unexpected difficulties or "messiness" involved.
ground_truth: The image is ironic because even though a boxer has won the match and it is supposed to be a moment of celebration, the boxer got bruised in several places during the match. This is an illustration of what hurdles a person has to go through in order to succeed.
